div.l: And þought alle þis nys nys don but for a wile
Þei wene þat noman may hem by gile
But be my þrift I shal found to blere here Eye
For alle þe sleight in here philosophie
The more queynte Crekes þat þei make
The more wil I stele whan I take
In stede of floure þan wil I ȝeue hem brenne
The grettest clerkes ben nouȝt þᵉ wisest men
As whilom to þe wolf þus spake þe Mare
Of alle her͗e arte count I nouȝt a tare
Out of þe dore he goth ful pⁱriuyly
Whan þat he saugh his tyme softly
He lokith vp and down til he hath fonde
The clerkes hors þer as it stode y bond
By hynde þe Mille vnder a leuesel
And to þᵉ hors hym goth faire and wel
He stripith of þe bridel faire a noon
And whan þe hors was laus he gynneþe gon
Toward þe fene þer wild mares renne
And forth with we he þourgh þikk ⁊and þynne
This Miller goth a gayn no word he said
But doth his notes and with his clerkes pleid
Til þat her corne was faire ⁊and wel y grond
And whan þe Mele is sacked and y bond
This Iohn goth out ⁊and fynd his hors a way
And gan to cry haro and welaway
Oure hors is lost Aleyn for goddes bones
Step on þi feet come of man alle at onys
Alas oure wardeyn hath his palfray lorn
This Aleyn Alle for ȝete both mele ⁊and corn
Alle was oute of mynd his husbondry
What whilk way is he gon he con to crye
Þe wif come rennyng Inward atte a renne
She saide Alas ȝour hors goth to þe fenne
With wild mares as faste as he may go
Vnthonk com on his hond þat bond hym so
And he þat bett̉er shuld haue knyt þe reyne
